description: British slang from 1941; possibly onomatopoeic of the sound of detonated bombs in the distance.

examples: He should have stepped back and given Hemi room to chat and see where the women was going, yet he found himself drawn over to them. His friend would probably give him a clobber later on for his stupidity  […]

entries.meaning: A bash on say the head, typically with a tool or object rather than with fists.

verbs.description: clobber (third-person singular simple present clobbers, present participle clobbering, simple past and past participle clobbered)

entries.meaning: (transitive, slang) To hit or bash severely; to seriously harm or damage.
examples: So the temptation to clobber was always there, and it was sometimes more difficult not to strike than it would have been to strike, and the consequences be damned.

entries.meaning: (transitive, computing, slang) To overwrite (data) or override (an assignment of a value), often unintentionally or unexpectedly.
examples: Inferences made in accordance with this reason are defeated by finding that the merged plan clobbers one of the causal-links in one of the constituent plans.

description: British slang from 19th century of unknown origin, perhaps from Yiddish.

examples: I was thinkin' of the widow while I gets me clobber on— / Like a feller will start thinkin' of the times that's past an' gone.

description: Of obscure origin, but compare clabber (“mud, wet clay”).

entries.meaning: A paste used by shoemakers to hide the cracks in leather.
